channel.title: [Help] Creating a user input page to transmit data onto html document
channel.description: So the title probably makes no sense what so ever. But this is to continue my websites development. What I am trying to do is make personal templates, say for a user to select and then have it auto fill data. I'm probably getting ahead of myself as I haven't got image uploading set up yet. Anyways, I'm sure I could write the html side of the document, but not the (assumption) php or all of the template (as it would need to take the php generated data and place it into the correct fields). Simple things are needed for now, like Name, Age, DoB, Gender, About me. I could possibly make the a profile image area a tag and have the scr be imported through one of the input fields. Please help anyone.

item.title: [Help] Creating a user input page to transmit data onto html document
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

Guys I think I can handle this. My teacher gave me a book on friday about databases. “The Manga Guide To Databases” xD win

Read full topic
item.source: [Help] Creating a user input page to transmit data onto html document

item.title: [Help] Creating a user input page to transmit data onto html document
item.dc:creator: @The_Web_Guy The Web Guy
item.description:
@The_Web_Guy wrote:

$_GET retrieves variables from the querystring or a URL.
$_POST retrieves variables from a POST method, usually forms.
There is also $_REQUEST which is somewhat a combination of the two.

That is my understanding on the topic.

Read full topic
item.source: [Help] Creating a user input page to transmit data onto html document

item.title: [Help] Creating a user input page to transmit data onto html document
item.dc:creator: @sppt sppt
item.description:
@sppt wrote:

ranger squad:

$_GET can be used for navigation but not for submission

False, it can be used for both.
$_GET is however a bit less secure, everyone that wants to make something safe uses POST

Read full topic

item.source: [Help] Creating a user input page to transmit data onto html document

item.title: [Help] Creating a user input page to transmit data onto html document
item.dc:creator: @justaguy justaguy
item.description:
@justaguy wrote:

[quote=“Ecko, post:7, topic:460529”][quote author=Ruby link=topic=563457.msg4107236#msg4107236 date=1348131779]

I can’t ever find a decent MySQL tutorial out there, I’ve done plenty of research.

Google “MySQL INSERT html form”, you should find an easy tutorial.

Basically you take all the inputs from the form with $_GET:

$name = $_GET['name']

Then use MySQL INSERT to insert all the user inputs into the database for storing.

Just make sure you are using $_GET on the correct input names.

I’d personally use $_POST.
[/quote]
You’re right, using $_POST is the correct variable to use with forms. I guess I had it in my head that $_GET retrieves data when I should have been thinking about posting data instead.[/quote]

They’re used in different circumstances, just know the differences.

Read full topic
item.source: [Help] Creating a user input page to transmit data onto html document

item.title: [Help] Creating a user input page to transmit data onto html document
item.dc:creator: @The_Web_Guy The Web Guy
item.description:
@The_Web_Guy wrote:

This ties into PHP; a Scripting language, and some SQL as Ecko suggested. You’ll basically want a user to submit a form, the form then sends the information to a database, where the information is logged. Then you’d use some PHP to display the information in the format of something like so…

That would display the link to a users profile image or user image or something, an example of using this would be…

I would suggest looking at some tutorials online that involve PHP and SQL. I’d recommend starting with a simple log-in system.

Read full topic
item.source: [Help] Creating a user input page to transmit data onto html document

item.title: [Help] Creating a user input page to transmit data onto html document
item.dc:creator: @Ecko Ecko
item.description:
@Ecko wrote:

You need to set up a MySQL database/table (preferably called ‘users’) so that you can store/retrieve the name/age/dob/gender/etc about a user.

At least that what I think you’re wanting. Difficult to understand what you want.

Read full topic
